item.title: Trump’s Speech on Economy Veers Into an Anti-Immigrant Tirade
item.description: President Trump vacillated between demonizing immigrants and assuring a crowd of his supporters that life was better than ever under his administration.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump spoke to his supporters at the Mount Airy Casino Resort in Mount Pocono, Pa., on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Administration Withdraws Plan to Overhaul Homeless Aid
item.description: The abrupt decision to revise the plan added new uncertainty and possible delays into the government’s distribution of $3.9 billion in homelessness relief.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: A homeless camp outside Suisun City, Calif., last month.

item.title: Democrats Say Hegseth Balked at Call for Full Video of Boat Strike
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed congressional leaders on Tuesday about the monthslong military campaign targeting people suspected of being drug traffickers at sea.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Revives Attacks on Fed Members Before Interest Rate Decision
item.description: Without evidence, the president claimed that some Fed governors might have been appointed using an autopen.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump called Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, a “bad head of the Fed” during a speech in Pennsylvania on Tuesday.

item.title: Inside the Pentagon’s Scramble to Deal With Boat Strike Survivors
item.description: Officials initially weighed sending survivors of U.S. attacks on boats suspected of drug smuggling to a notorious prison in El Salvador, to keep them away from American courts.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Edward Wong and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Recent news reports on strike orders given by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth have raised questions of potential war crimes.

item.title: Democrat Eileen Higgins Wins Miami Runoff Election to Become City’s First Female Mayor
item.description: Eileen Higgins, a former Miami-Dade County commissioner, will also be the city’s first female mayor and the first non-Hispanic mayor since the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eileen Higgins in Miami in November.

item.title: Trump Says Americans Are Doing Great, Even as Views on the Economy Sour
item.description: President Trump’s speech in Pennsylvania was meant to alleviate concerns about affordability. But he kept wandering off script and dwelling on his favorite targets, like immigration.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump delivering remarks on the economy at the Mount Airy Casino Resort in Mount Pocono, Pa., on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump’s Nvidia Chip Deal Reverses Decades of Technology Restrictions
item.description: President Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its chips to China has raised questions about whether he is prioritizing short-term economic gain over long-term American security interests.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, at the White House in April.

item.title: At State Dept., a Typeface Falls Victim in the War Against Woke
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio called the Biden-era move to the sans serif typeface “wasteful,” casting the return to Times New Roman as part of a push to stamp out diversity efforts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House last month.

item.title: Bird Flu Is Suspected After Vulture Carcasses Sat Rotting Outside Ohio School
item.description: The birds lingered for days at a Catholic school near Cincinnati as agencies haggled over who was responsible for removing them. Officials said the public health risk was low.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Stephen Miller’s Stock Sale Raises Questions, Ethics Experts Say
item.description: Mr. Miller, one of President Trump’s top advisers, sold shares in the mining company MP Materials following a lucrative deal between the company and the government.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, one of the president’s top advisers, sold shares of a mining company after it had begun negotiations with the government, raising concerns among ethics experts.

item.title: GOP Senators Will Counter Democrats’ Bid to Preserve Health Care Subsidies
item.description: Senate Republicans plan to offer a proposal that would create a new payment for people with bare-bones health coverage, clashing with Democrats who are pressing for an extension of existing tax credits.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator John Thune, the South Dakota Republican and majority leader, at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: After Trump Threatens Tariffs, Mexico Seeks a Deal on Water
item.description: President Trump threatened 5 percent tariffs on Mexican imports over a water dispute. Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, wants an agreement instead.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum told reporters on Tuesday that she would find a solution “that does not put the population and agricultural production in Mexico at risk, but that can also help the United States.”

item.title: Asserting a Personal Role in Warner Bros. Battle, Trump Seeks to Expand His Powers Again
item.description: The move comes as the Supreme Court also appears poised to put antitrust enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission under his control.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Warner Bros. Studios complex in Burbank, Calif.

item.title: Student Is Killed in Shooting at Kentucky State University
item.description: A suspect who is not a student was arrested after the shooting in Frankfort, Ky., the police said. The university said that a second student was critically injured.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Rylee Kirk and Corinne Boyer
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: The Kentucky State University campus in Frankfort, Ky., where the police responded to a shooting on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Somali Americans Are Carrying Proof of Citizenship Amid ICE Raids
item.description: In Minnesota, Somali Americans have been in fear since President Trump called them “garbage.” ICE raids across the state have led to over a dozen arrests, prompting many to carry their U.S. passports to protect against wrongful arrests.
item.dc:creator: Bethlehem Feleke, Jeremy Raff and Mark Boyer
item.media:credit: Jeremy Raff/The New York Times

item.title: A History of U.S. Military Action in Latin America
item.description: The United States’ history in the region includes several about-faces, contradictions and missteps.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: HUM Images/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: U.S. troops in Veracruz, Mexico, in April 1914, as part of a blockade of the city’s port.

item.title: Trump Administration Fights Roadblock to Pursuing Comey Case
item.description: The battle preceded the department’s looming decision over whether — and how — to bring new charges against James B. Comey.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
item.media:description: A ruling by a federal judge over the weekend has temporarily blocked prosecutors from gaining access to a crucial trove of evidence they used to bring charges against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, in late September.

item.title: Gov. Pritzker Signs Bill Imposing New Limits on Immigration Enforcement in Illinois
item.description: The measure restricts immigration arrests around state courthouses. Republicans have criticized the law and suggested it would face legal challenges.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois appeared in Chicago in October at a protest against the Trump administration.

item.title: Judge Suggests Lindsey Halligan, Prosecutor on Comey and James Cases, Should Resign
item.description: Lindsey Halligan’s indictments against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and Letitia James, the attorney general of New York, were dismissed last month over Ms. Halligan’s appointment.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Al Drago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lindsey Halligan at the White House in March.

item.title: Trump Calls Europe ‘Decaying’ and Suggests ‘Size Will Win’ in Ukraine War
item.description: President Trump’s comments deepened his rift with mainstream European leaders over defense and Ukraine policy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and other European leaders during a meeting at the White House earlier this year.

item.title: Supreme Court Struggles With How to Insulate the Federal Reserve From Politics
item.description: The president seemed poised for a big Supreme Court win letting him remove officials without cause. But the justices appeared to struggle with how to insulate the Federal Reserve from politics.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has mused about trying to fire Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, but he has not followed through. Indeed, no president has sought to remove a member of the Fed board without cause.

item.title: Three Years After Dobbs, the State Divide Over Abortion Deepens
item.description: The state divide over abortions has only deepened since the Supreme Court decision. But research shows the number of abortions has climbed.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Julia Rendleman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Choices, one of three clinics providing abortion services in Carbondale, a small town in southern Illinois, last week.

item.title: Supreme Court Grapples With Whether to Lift Campaign Finance Limits
item.description: The dispute before the court involved a Republican effort to lift limits on how much money political parties can spend in coordination with candidates.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2010, in the landmark case Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court struck down legal limits on independent political spending by corporations and unions.

item.title: Kamala Harris Isn’t Ready to Be Written Off
item.description: She was seen for two decades as a future face of the Democratic Party. Is she now suddenly a figure of its past?
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Vincent Alban
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times

item.title: In L.A., $750 a Month to Live in a Backyard Storage Unit
item.description: A landlord crowded tenants into his house and yard without running water or power. One, determined to find an alternative, was up against the city’s housing crisis.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m just kind of done living like this,” Junior Estrada said.
